author: Joe Mewis
title: Liverpool loan watch: How Jurgen Klopp's 13 loanees are doing this season - and what their future prospect are
text:
Ward has been key for the Terriers (Photo: Huddersfield Examiner) 
Age : 23 
On loan at : Huddersfield Town 
Appearances : 32 
Possibly the best loan spell of the lot. Ward has been a regular between the sticks for David Wagner's promotion-chasing side turning in a number of strong performances and getting some genuinely valuable experience. 
Ward will no doubt be a key player as the Yorkshire side press for promotion to the Premier League and has done enough to give himself a good chance of being involved with Klopp's first-team squad next week. 
In an ideal word this would be how all loan moves pan out, with both parties benefiting from the young stopper's spell across the Pennines. 
Chances of getting into first team: 8/10 Pedro Chirivella - Go Ahead Eagles Chirivella has made the switch to the Netherlands (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Age : 19 
On loan at : Go Ahead Eagles 
Appearances : 7 
Another January loanee following half a season with the under-23 side and has made a strong start in the Netherlands. 
Operating as a playmaker, he has already shown his ability to influence games, setting up an assist for Arsenal loanee Dan Crowley last weekend. If the teenage Spaniard can turn in some more impressive performances during the run-in then he will give Klopp another option next season. 
Chances of getting into first team : 7/10 Allan Allan is still grappling with work permit issues (Photo: John Powell) 
Age : 19 
On loan at : Hertha BSC 
Appearances : 8 
While the Brazilian has not received as much playing time as he would have hoped for, there are some positives to be gleaned. 
The Bundesliga is a significant step up from his spells in Iceland and Belgium and he has shown that he is developing physically and increasing his strength on the ball, a vital attribute if he is to succeed in the Premier League. 
One key facet of the move is to gain regular playing time in order to land a work permit, so he needs more playing time - and that could be a deciding factor in his Anfield future. 
Chances of getting into first team : 5/10 Taiwo Awoniyi Awoniyi was snapped up by Liverpool in 2015 (Photo: Dean Mouhtaropoulos - FIFA) 
Age : 19 
On loan at : NEC 
Appearances : 13 
Still very raw, Awoniyi has made the step up to the Eredivisie where he has struggled to make much of an impression on the first-team. A slow start saw him lose his place in the first-team but he has begun to notch up some goals in the reserve team. 
Unless he can force his way back into the first-team picture then it's hard to see this loan spell going down as a success.
